choices.text: 4 cm
6 cm
8 cm
10 cm

questions.text: A 24 y primigravida is in active labor. On the CTG, the following CTG is observed. What is the likely cervical dilatation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 10 cm

 

  • The image shows early decelerations as the nadir of the deceleration corresponds to the peak of contraction. Early decelerations are seen due to head compression which can be seen commonly in the 2nd stage of labor when head descent happens. Hence this image is likely to be when the cervix is 10 cm dilated (2nd stage)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of decelerations on a Cardiotocograph (CTG)

 

1. Early Deceleration:

 

  • The nadir of the deceleration corresponds to the peak of contraction
  • Due to head compression
  • Common in 2nd stage of labor (full dilatation of the cervix)

 

 

2.  Late Decelerations: 

 

  • The nadir (dip) of the deceleration occurs after the peak of contraction
  • Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency (fetal distress/ hypoxia)
  • It is an ominous sign

 

 

3.  Variable Decelerations

 

  • There is no fixed relationship between decelerations and the uterine contractions
  • Seen due to cord compression (oligohydramnios)
  • Significant if
  1. Persistent
  2. FHR < 70 bpm > 60 sec

 

 

Ref: Page no 468, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Cord compression
Fetal Hypoxia
Head compression
Cord Prolapse

questions.text: A 24 y primigravida is in active labor at 41 weeks. The CTG shows the following trace at 6 cm cervical dilatation. This indicates?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fetal Hypoxia

 

  • The image shows late deceleration (as the nadir of the deceleration is occurring after the peak of the contraction)
  • Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency (fetal distress/ hypoxia)
  • It is an ominous sign

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Cord compression results in variable decelerations wherein there is no relationship between the decelerations and uterine contractions
  • Option C: Head compression results in early decelerations wherein the nadir of the deceleration corresponds to the peak of the uterine contraction
  • Option D: Cord prolapse results in prolonged decelerations (i.e. deceleration > 2 mins 10 mins)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Late decelerations are a sign of utero placental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia

 

Ref: Page no 466, Williams 25th edition

choices.text: External fetal heart rate monitoring
Internal fetal heart rate monitoring
Fetal scalp blood sampling
Amniotic Fluid Index

questions.text: Which is not a method of intrapartum fetal monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Amniotic Fluid Index

 

Amniotic fluid index is a method of antepartum fetal monitoring and is a component of the modified biophysical profile

 

Methods of intrapartum fetal monitoring include

 

  • Intermittent auscultation
  • Electronic fetal heart rate monitoring           
    • External
    • Internal
  • Fetal scalp blood stimulation
  • Vibroacoustic stimulation
  • Intrapartum umbilical artery doppler
  • Fetal scalp blood pH
  • Fetal scalp blood lactate
  • Fetal ECG
  • Fetal pulse oximetry
  • Near Infrared Spectroscopy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods of intrapartum fetal monitoring include

 

  • Intermittent auscultation
  • Electronic fetal heart rate monitoring           
    • External
    • Internal
  • Fetal scalp blood stimulation
  • Vibroacoustic stimulation
  • Intrapartum umbilical artery doppler
  • Fetal scalp blood pH
  • Fetal scalp blood lactate
  • Fetal ECG
  • Fetal pulse oximetry
  • Near Infrared Spectroscopy

 

Ref: Page no 567, Dc Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: A pH < 7.20 indicates fetal hypoxia and necessitates urgent delivery
A normal fetal lactate level is > 4.8 mmol/L
It can be done only when the woman is in active labor with ruptured membranes
It is contra-indicated in < 34 weeks period of gestation

questions.text: A 34y G2 is in labor. Due to persistent late decelerations, a fetal scalp blood sample is taken. Which is incorrect regarding fetal scalp blood sampling?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A normal fetal lactate level is > 4.8 mmol/L

 

Let’s discuss all the options:

 

  • Option A: A pH < 7.20 indicates fetal hypoxia and necessitates urgent delivery: This is correct.
  • Option B: A normal fetal lactate level is > 4.8 mmol/L: This is incorrect. A normal lactate level is ≤ 4.1 mmol/l
  • Option C: It can be done only when the woman is in active labor with ruptured membranes. This is correct as the fetal scalp is accessible only through an adequately open os with ruptured membranes
  • Option D: It is contra-indicated in < 34 weeks period of gestation. This is also correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal Scalp Blood Sampling

 

  • Indicated in abnormal CTG to confirm fetal hypoxia
  • Values
    • < 7.20: Fetal acidosis and necessitates urgent delivery
    • pH between 7.21 and 7.25: borderline; Repeat within 30 minutes
    • pH > 7.25: Reassuring
  • Procedure
    • Mother in left lateral position
    • An illuminated plastic cone inserted through the dilated cervix (at least 4 – 5 cm dilatation required)
    • An incision of 2 mm made with a lancet
    • 35μl blood is adequate for estimation of pH
  • Contra-Indications
    • When spontaneous delivery is imminent
    • Preterm (< 34 weeks)
    • Fetal coagulation defects
    • Maternal infection (HIV, Hepatitis, Herpes simplex)
  • Fetal lactate measurements require lesser amount of blood (7 μl).
    • Normal fetal lactate: ≤ 4.1 mmol/l
    • Borderline: 4.2 – 4.8 mmol/l
    • Abnormal: > 4.9 mmol/l

 

Ref: Page no 470, Williams 25th edition, Fetal monitoring in labor (NICE GUIDELINE 2022)

choices.text: Fetal intracranial haemorrhage
Anti-D allo-immunization
Fetal parvovirus infection
Utero placental insufficiency

questions.text: Which of the below mentioned causes will not cause the fetal heart rate pattern shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Utero placental insufficiency

 

  • The image shows a sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern
  • It is seen in
    • Fetal intra-cranial haemorrhage
    • Severe fetal anemia as in
      • Anti-D alloimmunization
      • Vasa previa
      • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome
      • Fetal parvo virus infection
      • Feto-maternal haemorrhage
    • Maternal meperidine administration

 

Thus, the answer is option Utero-placental insufficiency. It does not show a sinusoidal pattern (It shows late decelerations)

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • The image shows a sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern
  • It is seen in
    • Fetal intra-cranial haemorrhage
    • Severe fetal anemia as in
      • Anti-D alloimmunization
      • Vasa previa
      • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome
      • Fetal parvo virus infection
      • Feto-maternal haemorrhage
    • Maternal meperidine administration

 

Ref: Page no 464, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: The onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the beginning, peak and ending of the contraction, respectively
The onset of the deceleration occurs before the beginning of the contraction, but the nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the peak and ending of the contraction, respectively
The onset and nadir of the deceleration occur before the beginning and peak of the contraction, respectively, but the recovery of the deceleration occurs after the ending of the contraction
The onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur before the beginning, peak and ending of the contraction, respectively

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding late decelerations?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the beginning, peak and ending of the contraction, respectively.

 

Explanation:

 

Late Decelerations

 

  • The onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the beginning, peak and ending of the contraction, respectively
  • The deceleration reaches its nadir within 30 seconds of its onset
  • Causes
    • Uteroplacental insufficiency
    • Maternal hypotension
    • Uterine hyperactivity

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 466, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Oligohydramnios
Meconium-stained amniotic fluid
Head compression
Cord prolapse

questions.text: A 22y primi in labor at 38 weeks has ruptured her membranes spontaneously at 5 cm dilatation. On the CTG, the below image is seen. The most likely cause is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cord prolapse

 

Explanation

 

Prolonged Deceleration

 

  • Defined as an isolated deceleration ≥ 15 bpm that lasts ≥ 2 minutes but < 10 mins from onset to return to baseline
  • Causes
    • Epidural or spinal anesthesia
    • Placental abruption
    • Cord prolapse
    • Umbilical cord knots
    • Eclampsia
    • Epilepsy
    • Application of a fetal scalp electrode
    • Maternal Valsalva manuever
  • In the scenario given, the deceleration occurs after rupture of membranes. 2 common causes of prolonged deceleration following rupture of membranes are: cord prolapse and abruptio placentae.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Oligohydramnios: This will lead to variable decelerations
  • Option B. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid: In fetal hypoxia this would lead to late decelerations
  • Option C. Head compression: This will result in early decelerations

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prolonged Deceleration

 

  • Defined as an isolated deceleration ≥ 15 bpm that lasts ≥ 2 minutes but < 10 mins from onset to return to baseline
  • Causes
    • Epidural or spinal anesthesia
    • Placental abruption
    • Cord prolapse
    • Umbilical cord knots
    • Eclampsia
    • Epilepsy
    • Application of a fetal scalp electrode
    • Maternal Valsalva manuever

 

Ref: Page 468, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Fetal scalp electrode
Fetal scalp blood sampler
Fetal ECG probe
CTG

questions.text: Identify the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fetal scalp electrode

 

  • This is an image of fetal scalp electrodes.
  • They are used in internal electronic fetal monitoring during labor
  • Intrauterine pressure can also be measured simultaneously by passing a catheter in the uterine cavity
  • Internal monitoring can be done only when the cervix is at least 3-4 cm dilated and the membranes have ruptured.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • This is an image of fetal scalp electrodes.
  • They are used in internal electronic fetal monitoring during labor

 

Ref: Page no 567, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: Immediate cesarean section
Forceps delivery
Repeat scalp blood pH within 30 mins
Hydrate the patient and start O2

questions.text: A 24-year primigravida is in labor. At 5cm dilatation, a CTG taken shows late decelerations. A fetal scalp blood sample reveals a pH of 7.19. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Immediate cesarean section

 

  • As the pH of fetal scalp blood is < 7.20, this means the baby is already hypoxic and acidotic and needs immediate delivery.
  • At 5 cm, the best way to do this would be by an emergency LSCS.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Forceps delivery: This is incorrect as a forceps can only be applied when the cervix is fully dilated
  • Option C. Repeat scalp blood pH within 30 mins: This is also incorrect as the fetus is already acidotic
  • Option D. Hydrate the patient and start O2: As the fetus is already acidotic hydration and oxygen will not help

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 570, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition
